The Wolf's Cookbook

Food By Geeks, For Geeks

The classic Japanese noodle soup, with nearly every region of the country having its own variation. After World War 2 it started to become a staple of the struggling nation thanks to cheap wheat flour flooding in from the United States. Then, in 1958, the Found and Chairman of Nissin Foods—Momofuku Ando (安藤 百福) invented instant Ramen. In the 1980's this food was becoming a Japanese cultural icon and the low price of the Instant variety has seen it become a staple food of cash-strapped college students everywhere. Presented here is an attempt at a much healthier version of the classic. Do note that this has some preparatory steps that need to be done hours before actually preparing the final dish.

Ingredients

  • Marinade
    • Liquids
      • ½ cupSoy Sauce
      • 2 tbspMirin
      • 1 tbspSesame Oil
    • Other
      • 1 tbspSugar
        • Turbinado or other "unrefined" sugars are fine
      • 1 tbspGarlic Powder
      • 1 tspFresh Grated Ginger
      • ½ tspGround Black Pepper
      • ½ tbspChopped Scallions or Chives
  • Broth
      • 6 cupsWater
      • 3 tbsp Soy Sauce
      • 1 tspDark Soy Sauce
      • 1 tbspMiso Paste
        • This can be difficult to find, but is available on Amazon
      • 1 tspSesame Oil
      • 1 tbspBeef Bouillon Powder
        • or an equivalent amount in the classic cube form
  • Soup
    • Meats
      • 1 to 1½ poundsSkirt Steak or \"asian cut\" beef
    • Vegetables
      • 1 mediumWhite Onion
        • Dice half, cut the half other into thin strips
      • 1 mediumGreen Bell Pepper
        • Dice the entire thing
      • ½ cupGreen Onions
        • You can also use scallions or spring onions
      • ½ cupCarrot
        • Thin strips or julienned, your choice
      • ¼ cupChives
    • Other
      • 2 tbspSesame Oil
      • 3 to 4 tbspThickener
        • Flour or a vegetable starch, such as Mung Bean or Corn Starch
      • Noodles
        • I've use low mein noodles as well as the classic wheat noodle that is so well known from Ramen. Chefs choice!
      • Marinade
        • You make this as part of the process

Instructions

  • Marinade

    Make this 12 to 24 hours ahead of time!
    1. Mix liquid ingredients
    2. Whisk in vegetables and spices
    3. Cover and chill in refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours

  • Meat Prep

    Do this at least 6 hours ahead of time
    1. Cut meat into small chunks—but no smaller than about 1½ inches by 1 inch
    2. Put meat in marinade. Make sure its fully submerged, cover/close the container
    3. Put the marinating meat in a refrigerator

  • Broth Wet Mix

    Do this immediately before starting
    1. Mix Soy Sauce, Dark Soy Sauce, Sesame Oil and Miso in sealable container.
    2. Close/seal container and set aside for later use

  • The Ramen

    This is what you're here for
    1. Remove meat from marinade, dredge in flour/starch and sear in hot pan with a little bit of your choice of cooking oil.
    2. Set meat aside and add the sesame oil to the pan along with the vegetables. Mix well and gently sautee, possibly adding a pinch of salt.
    3. Add meat, water for the broth and the boillon. Bring to a boil.
    4. Add the noodles and broth base mix. Cook until noodles are done.
    5. Ramen is ready to serve.
      • The marinade can be re-used, but experience shows that its effectiveness in adding flavor drops off fast.
